𝗜𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗹𝗱 𝗚𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝘀𝗲 𝗼𝗿 𝗜𝘀 𝗜𝘁 𝗢𝗻𝗹𝘆 𝗢𝘂𝗿 𝗣𝗲𝗿𝗰𝗲𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻?
If we follow the news today, we see a world about to collapse, as if we were experiencing the worst time ever. Therefore, we are able to believe that our grandparents were right, longing for "the good old days."
Grim indicators abound–extreme heat waves and raging fires in Europe and the United States, America bleeding between one mass shooting and the next, inflation reaching historic highs to the point that recession seems likely, the unending Russian war in Ukraine continuing to cause shockwaves across the globe.
Britain and Italy face political instability. Sri Lanka sank in front of people's eyes while its leaders fled the country. The quiet country of Japan saw the assassination of its former prime minister in the daylight.
As shocking as everything looks, nothing has changed that much in the world. The main change has been in the accumulation of information and people's connections in the world. In past times we set out on walking tours to hear what was going on in the neighboring town and rocked inside a ship for two months to get to know a distant country.
In later periods, we bought a ticket for a high-speed train or took planes to land on a distant continent to know other realities and people. Now without getting up from the chair and with the press of a key we are there, in the heart of the world. In less than a second, the entire colorful, noisy and bustling reality unfolds before us, stunning us with its growing influence.
We hear and see, feel, admire and respond to everything that happens to everyone in every corner in real time. Communication between us requires us to absorb an intensive flow of information which we consume like addicts.
How often does someone read a book and go to a friend to share, "Listen, what a good book I read!” We are in a world that is all news that we are not built to absorb, engagements that we are unable to tolerate. As a consequence, people are getting sicker physically and mentally.
The endless bonds formed between us are cold, flat and alienated. They have no depth, warmth or identification. They lack sympathy and willingness to approach, and do not take into account that we are one. If the world seems full of crises, it is the ties between us that are broken.
The physical bonds between us have become tight and fast, and so it should be, but we need to adjust ourselves internally and emotionally to it. We need to insert warmth within these bonds that will strengthen and connect us instead of breaking us apart. You can turn off the news a bit, open a purposeful book, talk to each other, and feel each other.
Instead of running around with eyes on the monitor and absorbing fragmented pieces of information, we can get a real picture of reality when we look at creation as integral, knowing that it has direction and purpose. All of reality, past or present has a single purpose: to make us perceive that we are one, like nature, and to understand that only through our mutual guarantee and interdependence will we be able to overcome any hardship. When we achieve this perspective, the perception of the world that we see will finally come into a beautiful balance called peace.

Why do you continually lie about the theory of 'evolution'? "Evolution" mixes two things together, one real, one imaginary. People are shown the real part, which makes them ready to believe the imaginary part. That is how the idea of biological evolution has spread since 1859. Variation (microevolution) is the real part. The types of bird beaks, the colors of moths, leg sizes, etc. are variation. Each type and length of beak a finch can have is already in the gene pool and adaptive mechanisms of finches. Creationists have always agreed that there is variation within species. What evolutionists do not want you to know is that there are strict limits to variation that are never crossed, something every breeder of animals or plants is aware of. Whenever variation is pushed to extremes by selective breeding (to get the most milk from cows, sugar from beets, bristles on fruit flies, or any other characteristic), the line becomes sterile and dies out. And as one characteristic increases, others diminish. But evolutionists want you to believe that changes continue, merging gradually into new kinds of creatures. This is where the imaginary part of the theory of evolution comes in. It says that new information is added to the gene pool by mutation and natural selection to create frogs from fish, reptiles from frogs, and mammals from reptiles, to name a few.

Just to be clear, evolution theory puts no limit on what mutation/natural selection can invent, saying that everything in nature was invented by it - everything:
I merely scratched the surface debunking the evolution Lie, look it up for yourself and stop deceiving the people!!

When I was 12 or 13 I got bit by a brown recluse spider granted they are poisonous to begin with but add on the fact that I'm allergic to ant bites, mosquito bites etc and didn't know it so much at that point it hit me immediately. I was picking butter beans on my family farm and within two minutes my leg was turning dark purple. Most people say that they didn't even know they'd been bitten. Not me. I felt it. I felt it immediately and jumped up and saw it still on my leg. My mother took the spider and picked me up and threw me into the car. Granted if at home we lived within 1 minute to the hospital but on the farm we were more like 15 minutes from the hospital. When we got there and it was was within 8 minutes I was unresponsive. I lived in a smaller city at that time so they didn't have any antivenom on hand to treat me and it had to be helicoptered in for me. It took me a long time to get over that bite and I come very close to death. They saved my leg and I had gause stuck inside my leg with a small circular ring that hung on the outside so after a two weeks they could pull it out. I ended up getting this done twice. They also think this one bite at a young age caused my immune system to be more allergic to other bug bites like ants, bees, mosquitos, etc. After my case the hospital started carrying more treatments on hand for those that are all ready allergic because their reactions are already more lethal and quickly. My mom's quick thinking to take the spider also helped save my life and make their jobs so much easier than giving many treatments not knowing what type of spider that bit me and knowing from how fast I was turning to get me to the hospital immediately.

Aussie city kid here. Went for a roadtrip with a mate to visit his inter-state family in Orange, beautiful place, high elevation, rivers, great people. His grandfather was showing us around to a few friends and I was subjected to the cliche city kid routine 'Hey, come look at this mounted head of a Jackalope I caught once, they're vicious little buggers.' 'Be sure to watch out for Drop Bears' and the like. Anyhow, we're in the front yard and his grandfather yells at me 'Oi, stand perfectly still!' I looked over at him figuring it was another joke. Nope. He'd spotted an Eastern Brown Snake that came from under the veranda and slithered out straight between my legs. He may seriously have saved my life.

Antibodies are relatively complex proteins, with a 3D structure arranged in the reticulum of the cell. Bacteria can't produce it.
Even though the production of in vitro antibodies is not just possible but common. You have to isolate a plasmodium (antibodies producing cell) and fuse it with a cancer cell that reproduces continually.

It's a process commonly used for producing antibodies for scientific research, when you need to detect the presence of a protein.

So that guy loves animals. That’s probably why he makes them live horrific lives. A snake spending its whole life in a small box is like a human spending 80 years terrified inside a cube not even large enough to lie full-length. All I see here is pure torture. All this distress and suffering so that a few humans may survive bites from wild snakes, humans who would never have been bitten in the first place if they hadn’t encroached upon habitats they’re not supposed to venture in.

So, well, what can I say? You do great work, Derek, but not everything that’s "interesting" deserves a video. Animal abuse should not be taken slightly nor minimized. And here there’s essentially not much more than pure animal abuse. Of course, the animals’ point of view is never taken into account because of our anthropocentric bias. All that matters is humans, and making the life of a few humans simpler seems to justify torturing countless sentient creatures who—you will know it if you study it—do have feelings, express emotions and feel pain. This type of things should not be promoted lightly, in a candidly joyful manner. The story in which the snake rushed toward the door to escape isn't something one can simply smile at; it is sheer horror for that poor creature.

Since you love science, you should do a series of videos on animal sentience and add a philosophical dimension to your research in that field.

I sincerely hope you’ll do it.

Best,

As usual, I thank you for continuing to add content.     I never want to stop learning.    And, by the way, before I watched this latest video, I had assumed anti-venom was made in a way similar to making reagents.    As a former employee of a blood bank, I am really beginning to wonder exactly what was done with the plasma we shipped overseas.   (All blood donations, which by law, MUST be donations if they are to be transfusable, are spun down to separate RBCs from plasma.   Plasma from male donors is either stored to use for transfusion, or flash-frozen to later harvest cryo-precipitate.  However, plasma from female donors may not be used for transfusion, due to TRALI, or Transfusion Induced Acute Lung Injury.   If a female transfusion patient receives plasma from another female donor,  an unintentional immune response is triggered, and just like the cytokine storm that Covid-19 causes, the lungs can be shut down, or severely damaged.   So we sent all female plasma overseas to be used to make coating for certain medicines, and also blood pathogen tests.   I now wonder how much of the process I have taken for granted.      oh, and  incidentally, cryo-precipitate, a dense collection of healing proteins most commonly used to promote recovery in surgical procedures, would be used to treat bites from a different venomous snake - one whose venom is flesh-eating)

Horse plasma is how anti tetanic antitoxin is made, or at least still is, I guess.
Before modern vaccines, if you got tetanus and were lucky enough to have access to a tetanus immune horse, you could receive it's blood, only once, in order to be able to live. My dad, now retired, used to work as a topographer in agricultural and forest areas here in Mexico. We do have our own amount of venomous snakes in the wilderness, so he and his coworkers had to take measures to avoid bites, like wearing boots and bringing snake bites antidote in their first-aid kit.

However, they always avoid snakes when a late friend of my dad, Mr. Guillermo, used to feel goosebumps from nowhere. Every time when Mr. Guillermos's goose bumps came, they always found a snake ahead in their way. They never knew why was that, but I do suspect that Mr. Guillermo had a gene or a random mutation that made him highly allergic to snakes, and that was what saved my dad and their coworkers a multiple times from getting bitten by rattlesnakes and coral snakes.

Great episode! Antivenom (antivenin!) from my understanding does not confer immunity. As it only supplies the antibodies but not the B cells that would make those antibodies. Quote from Wikipedia section:
"Surgeon-Major Edward Nicholson wrote in the November 1870 Madras Medical Journal that he had witnessed a Burmese snake-catcher inoculating himself with cobra venom. However, the snake-catcher was unsure whether this was actually effective and therefore continued to treat his snakes with care. Nicholson, along with other Britons, began to consider that venom might provide its own cure. Although Scottish surgeon Patrick Russell had noted in the late 18th century that snakes were not affected by their own venom,[22] it was not until the late 19th century that Joseph Frayer, Lawrence Waddell, and others began to consider venom-based remedies again. However, they and other naturalists working in India did not have the funding to fully develop their theories. Not until 1895 did Sir Thomas Fraser, Professor of Medicine at the University of Edinburgh, pick up Fayrer and Waddell's research to produce a serum to act against cobra venom. His 'Antivenin' was effective, but failed to make an impact as the public were focused on contemporary Pasteurian discoveries.[23]

Another anti-ophidic serum was developed by Albert Calmette, a French scientist of the Pasteur Institute working at its Indochine branch in 1895, to treat the bites of the Indian Cobra (Naja naja).[24]

In 1901, Vital Brazil, working at the Instituto Butantan in São Paulo, Brazil, developed the first monovalent and polyvalent antivenoms for Central and South American Crotalus and Bothrops genera,[25] as well as for certain species of venomous spiders, scorpions, and frogs.

In Australia, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (CSL) began antivenom research in the 1920s. CSL has developed antivenoms for the redback spider, funnel-web spiders and all deadly Australian snakes.[26] "

One of the other reasons Australia has such a low snake death rate is the type of toxin (and thus the first aid response) is the same for all of our venomous snakes - if i'm remembering correctly, all Australian snakes are neurotoxic and have quite small fangs as oppose to in say the Americas where both neurotoxic and cyto/myotoxic snakes are present and long fangs can complicate snake removal and penetrate to major blood vessels.

I have to make this correction, the inland taipan is not the most venomous snake on earth. Like he said at 7:05 , it's the *most toxic land snake. The Hook-nosed Sea Snake (Enhydrina schistosa) is in fact more venomous. But good luck getting most sea snakes to bite. There are several sea snakes that are more venomous, but they're usually not counted due to the fact that they rarely ever bite. Another thing is the fact that every snake is different and one individuals venom could be wildly more or less toxic than the next. So in herpetology, we generally don't look at whether one snake is the most venomous or not due to all of these variables. "Dead is dead" in the words of Jim Harrison, who owns the Kentucky reptile zoo and is a great friend of mine. I highly recommend watching the documentary "The Venom Interviews" to get a real look into the life of a herpetologist and venom extractor. Jim is one of the very few in the US who actually extracts venom from snakes for antivenom and medical research. I highly suggest doing a follow-up video with him. Yes, he has taipans, mambas (a few species), and every type of snake that you can think of and he has one of the largest collections of venomous snakes in the world.
I would have just left a gopro in the corner and waited in the hall while he milked those snakes.

Fun fact: everyone who gets involved in snake venom extraction develops a severe allergy to it over time as a result of the constant exposure to the venom aerosol. Snake bites are thus more dangerous to these people than they would be to a normal person. Props to all who are risking their lives each day to save others.

Can't tell if this is a new or old video in terms of the footage, but regardless, doing this without gloves has to be one of the stupidest things I've ever seen. Generally skin is a good barrier against fluids, however, the skin of certain parts of the body is far more susceptible to infiltration than others. Just so happens that the fingers all have this skin at the site of the cuticle. I sadly forget the technical term but it describs the skin at places like; the corner of the eyes, the cuticles of nails, the lips and inside of the mouth, the anus, and urethral openings. If that Inland Taipan is so dangerous, then simply the residue of the snake bite should be dangerous to come into contact with causing atleast light sicknesses without true ingestion. Obviously the glove wouldn't protect from a direct bite, but to suggest that he would use his finger as bait and essentially be in somewhat direct contact with the container that snake just sprayed venom in; it just sounds like deathwish stuff. I've seen the snake collar method where the snake is pulled back through a special collar it can't move out of. Way safer. No theatrics required.

As someone who studied immunology this seems rather strange to me. Since the Ab from horse are foreign to the body one should develop an immune response to these Abs. So I wonder is it the case, that antivenom is less effective in people who have received antivenom more than once? (theoretically, you should have anti-horse antibodies)
Furthermore, we have the technology to develop monoclonal Abs from hybridomas. Why the hell don't we just do that? No animals involved, just cells (I mean we still have to immunize mice for example and then collect their B cells, but after that, we can produce a lot of Abs with high purity and binding capacity. This should also reduce the danger of an allergic reaction)

i saw a really cool demonstration once at a trade show where they took the venom of a snake, i dont remember which one it was, whose venom specifically attacks the blood and forces it to clot rapidly. which sounds like just another thing you would hear on a BBC documentary about snakes right? but the demonstration they did was they took a bag of human blood and poured into a big transparent bowl. then they dropped a single bites worth of venom into the bowl of blood. within just a couple of seconds, that entire bowl of blood solidified inside the bowl. i mean it was solid enough to look like cranberry sauce at thanksgiving. or yams for some of you. and it was a lot of blood too, i mean it was a bag of donor blood. so that snake bites you, and all the blood in your system immediately clots inside your body. which is terrifying

Doulgas Adams met Struan Sutherland in Melbourne in the late 1980’s on his way to Indonesia to see the Dragons of Komodo with the zoologist Mark Cawardine.

There is in Melbourne a man who probably knows more about poisonous snakes than anyone else on earth. his name is Dr Struan Sutherland, and he has devoted his entire life to a study of venom.

‘And I’m bored with it,’ he said when we went along to see him the next morning. ‘Can’t stand all these poisonous creatures, all these snakes and insects and fish and things. Stupid things, biting everybody. And then people expect me to tell them what to do about it. I’ll tell them what to do. Don’t get bitten in the first place. That’s the answer. I’ve had enough of it. Hydroponics, now, that’s interesting. Talk to you all you like about hydroponics. Fascinating stuff, growing plants artificially in water, very interesting technique. We’ll need to know all about it if we’re go to Mars and places. Where did you say you were going?’

‘Komodo’

‘Well, don’t get bitten, that’s all I can say. And don’t come running to me if you do because you won’t get here in time and anyway I’ll probably be out. Hate this office, look at it. Full of poisonous animals all over the place. Look at this tank, it’s full of fire ants. Poisonous. Bored silly with them. Anyway, I got some little cakes in in case you were hungry. Would you like some little cakes? I can’t remember where I put them. There’s some tea but it’s not very good. Sit down for heaven’s sake.

‘So, you’re going to Komodo. Well, I don’t know why you want to do that, but I suppose you have your reasons. There are fifteen different types of snakes on Komodo, and half of them are poisonous. The only potentially deadly ones are the Russell’s viper, the bamboo viper, and the Indian cobra.

‘The Indian cobra is the fifteenth deadliest snake in the world, and all the other fourteen are here in Australia. That’s why it’s so hard for me to find time to get on with my hydroponics, with all these snakes all over the place.

…

We… asked him how many of the snakes he had been bitten by himself.

‘None of ’em’ he said. ‘Another area of expertise I’ve developed is that of getting other people to handle the dangerous animals. Won’t do it myself. Don’t want to get bitten do I? You know what it says in my entry in Who’s Who? “Hobbies: gardening – with gloves; fishing – with boots; traveling – with care.” That’s the answer. Oh, and wear baggy trousers. When a snake strikes it starts to inject venom as soon as it hits something. If you’ve got baggy trousers most of the venom will just get squirted down the inside of your trousers which is better than down the inside of your leg. You’re not eating your cakes. Come on, get them down you, there’s plenty more in the fridge.’

…

‘So what do we do if we get bitten by something deadly, then?’ I asked.
He blinked at me as if I were stupid.

‘Well what do you think you do?’ he said. ‘You die of course. That’s what deadly means.’

‘But what about cutting open the wound and sucking out the poison?’ I asked.

‘Rather you than me,’ he said. ‘I wouldn’t want a mouthful of poison. all the blood vessels beneath the tongue are very close to the surface so the poison goes straight into the bloodstream. That’s assuming you could get much of the poison out, which you probably couldn’t. And in a place like Komodo it means you’d quickly have a seriously infected wound to contend with as well as a leg full of poison. Septicaemia, gangrene, you name it. It’ll kill you.’

‘What about a tourniquet?’

‘Fine if you don’t mind having your leg off afterwards. You’d have to because it would be dead. And if you find anyone in that part of Indonesia who you’d trust to take your leg off then you’re a braver man than me. No, I’ll tell you: the only thing you can do is apply a pressure bandage direct to the wound and wrap the whole leg up tightly, but not too tightly. Slow the blood flow but don’t cut it off or you’ll lose the leg. keep the leg, or whatever bit of you it is you’ve been bitten in, lower than your heart and your head. Keep very, very still, breathe slowly and get to a doctor immediately. If you’re on Komodo that means a couple of days, by which time you’ll be well dead.

“The only answer, and I mean this quite seriously, is don’t get bitten. There’s no reason why you should. Any of the snakes there will get out of your way well before you even see them. You don’t really need to worry about the snakes if you’re careful. No, the things you really need to worry about are the marine creatures.’

‘What?’

‘Scorpion fish, stone fish, sea snakes. Much more poisonous than anything on land. Get stung by a stone fish and the pain alone can kill you. People drown themselves to stop the pain.’

‘Where are all these things?’

‘Oh, just in the sea. Tons of them. I wouldn’t go near it if I were you. Full of poisonous animals. Hate them.’

‘Is there anything you do like?’

‘Hydroponics.’

No, I mean is there any venomous creature you’re particularly fond of?’

He looked out of the window for a moment.
‘There was,’ he said, ‘but she left me’.
